prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits

Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. response.output:
Sure, here is the revised paragraph:

Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, impacting disease-relevant biological processes. Determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across multiple cell types, leading to improved treatments. Integrating functional genomics and GWAS data has significantly enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology.

response.output:
**Context:** Understanding how genetic variations influence complex traits requires a comprehensive approach that integrates genetic and functional data. Studying the interplay of genetic and environmental factors across different cell types is crucial to uncover the molecular mechanisms underlying tissue and cell lineage-specific diseases.

**Content:** Recent research has highlighted the importance of gene co-expression in understanding complex traits. However, conventional approaches to studying gene expression have limitations, particularly when considering the complexity and heterogeneity of biological systems. Functional genomics approaches provide valuable insights by integrating genetic and phenotypic data, enabling the identification of causal relationships and disease mechanisms.

**Conclusion:** Despite the progress in functional genomics and GWAS, our understanding of the genetic basis of complex traits is still incomplete. Integrating these approaches allows researchers to uncover the intricate interplay between genetic variations and environmental factors, ultimately leading to improved disease diagnosis and drug development strategies.

**Context:**
Determining how specific genetic variations influence complex traits, which often involve the interplay of multiple cell types and tissues, necessitates a deep understanding of gene expression patterns across diverse cell types.

**Content:**
Functional genomics data and genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have significantly contributed to our understanding of complex traits by revealing the involvement of genetic variants in shaping individual phenotypes. However, the exact mechanisms through which these genetic variations impact disease susceptibility remain largely unknown.

**Conclusion:**
The integration of functional genomics and GWAS data has provided valuable insights into the genetic basis of complex traits. By identifying the molecular mechanisms that are involved, this research has paved the way for the development of novel therapeutic strategies aimed at mitigating disease susceptibility and improving patient outcomes.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

response.output:
**Context:** 
Gene expression data across multiple tissues provides a rich resource for unraveling the etiology and drug mechanisms of complex diseases. However, traditional GWAS approaches, which focus on single genes, fail to capture the intricate interplay of genetic variants and biological processes that contribute to disease susceptibility.

**Content:**
The advent of high-throughput technologies has revolutionized our ability to study gene expression at a global scale. This has led to the development of powerful tools for integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data into GWAS analysis. These methods provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and diseases.

**Conclusion:**
The application of TWAS has significantly advanced our understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms. However, its focus on the individual gene level limits its ability to capture complex interactions at the network level. By employing TWAS, researchers can identify not only individual genetic risk factors but also the intricate interplay of genetic variants and biological processes that contribute to disease susceptibility.

response.output: Identifying disease etiology and drug mechanisms requires a comprehensive understanding of the genetic architecture of complex traits. While traditional GWAS relies on assessing individual gene expression, recent research has highlighted the importance of integrating information from a broader network of genes through approaches such as transcriptional-wide association studies (TWAS). This limitation is addressed by focusing on a broader set of genes and pathways through a network-based approach, thereby providing a more comprehensive understanding of the genetic architecture of complex traits.

response.output:
## Integrating gene expression data in TWAS: A window into complex disease etiology and drug repurposing.

Despite its success in uncovering disease etiology through GWAS, TWAS has limitations. By focusing on individual genes, it fails to capture the intricate network interactions that underpin complex diseases. This knowledge gap motivates the exploration of alternative approaches that can integrate gene expression data into GWAS analysis. Here, we explore the potential of integrating transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) with gene expression data to gain a deeper mechanistic understanding of disease etiology and identify novel therapeutic targets.

vars.content: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

response.output:
Sure, here is the revised paragraph from the Introduction section:

TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data across multiple tissues to elucidate the biological mechanisms underlying genetic variants associated with human diseases. By leveraging the wealth of information on gene expression across different tissues, TWAS provides a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings by capturing complex interactions at the network level. This approach complements other GWAS methods by integrating information on the regulation of gene expression, offering a more comprehensive understanding of the genetic basis of diseases.

response.output:
**Context:**
The field of genetic research has made significant strides in identifying genetic variants associated with complex diseases, including cancer and drug resistance. However, existing approaches, such as transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), have limitations in capturing the intricate interplay between genetic variants and disease risk.

**Content:**
This manuscript presents a novel approach to address this limitation by leveraging the power of gene expression data. By integrating information from gene co-expression networks, we gain a mechanistic understanding of genetic associations beyond the individual gene level. This approach, termed clustering of complex traits (CCT), facilitates the discovery of novel therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities.

**Conclusion:**
The inclusion of gene expression data in the analysis framework offers a powerful means to elucidate the etiology of diseases and identify novel therapeutic strategies. By bridging the gap between individual gene and network-level approaches, this study paves the way for a more comprehensive understanding of complex diseases and the development of personalized treatments.

vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

response.output:
Sure, here's the revised paragraph:

Given the availability of extensive gene expression data across multiple tissues, an effective approach to identify biological processes is the integration of expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data into genome-wide association studies (GWAS) to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, eQTLs analysis is not limited to individual genes and can capture complex interactions at the network level. By testing the association between genetic variants and human diseases, eQTLs have successfully identified disease etiology at the transcriptome level, contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores), and facilitated drug repurposing.

response.output: Integrating large-scale gene expression data into functional genomics approaches offers a powerful avenue for dissecting disease etiology and identifying therapeutic targets. However, traditional approaches focusing solely on individual genes fail to capture the intricate network-level interactions that underpin complex diseases. Recent advancements in transcriptomic research have highlighted the potential of transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) in elucidating the etiology of diseases by integrating information from genome-wide expression data. TWAS has proven remarkably successful in unraveling the genetic architecture of various diseases, including cancer and cardiovascular disorders, by identifying genetic variants associated with disease risk and progression. Notably, TWAS has been instrumental in uncovering disease mechanisms and developing personalized therapeutic strategies through repurposing of existing drugs.

response.output:
## Integrating gene co-expression and functional genomics for disease etiology and drug repurposing.

Despite the wealth of genetic data, identifying the biological processes underlying complex diseases remains a significant challenge. While traditional GWAS approaches have proven successful in uncovering disease etiology at the single-gene level, they fail to capture the intricate interactions occurring at the network level. This is particularly relevant in diseases with multiple genetic causes, where a single genetic variant may be implicated in disease development through diverse pathways.

By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data into GWAS, we can leverage the strengths of both approaches. This approach provides a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings by identifying the co-expression of genes in disease-associated pathways. This information can guide the discovery of novel therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities.

**Context:**
Determining how specific genetic variations influence complex traits, which often involve the interplay of multiple cell types and tissues, necessitates a deep understanding of gene expression patterns across diverse cell types.

**Content:**
Functional genomics data and genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have significantly contributed to our understanding of complex traits by revealing the involvement of genetic variants in shaping individual phenotypes. However, the exact mechanisms through which these genetic variations impact disease susceptibility remain largely unknown.

**Conclusion:**
The integration of functional genomics and GWAS data has provided valuable insights into the genetic basis of complex traits. By identifying the molecular mechanisms that are involved, this research has paved the way for the development of novel therapeutic strategies aimed at mitigating disease susceptibility and improving patient outcomes.

Identifying genetic associations at the network level, where multiple genes interact to influence disease risk, is a challenging task. Recent advancements in high-throughput technologies have yielded extensive gene expression data across various tissues, providing an opportunity to investigate these complex interactions. Notably, transcriptional-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful tool for uncovering disease etiology and drug mechanisms. TWAS integrates gene expression data with GWAS findings, leveraging the ability of the expression data to capture network-level interactions. This approach has facilitated significant advancements in understanding disease pathogenesis, predicting disease risk, and identifying drug repurposing opportunities. However, while TWAS offers valuable insights at the individual gene level, it does not provide a comprehensive understanding of complex interactions at the network level.

Identifying disease etiology and drug mechanisms from genetic studies requires an integrative approach that considers both individual gene expression and network-level interactions. Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), which leverage eQTL data, offer a powerful tool for this purpose. By testing for the association between genetic variants and disease risk through the mediation of gene regulatory mechanisms, TWAS provides mechanistic insights into disease etiology and drug repurposing. However, its focus on the individual gene level limits its ability to capture complex network interactions that are crucial for understanding the underlying mechanisms of complex traits.

**Context:** 
Gene expression data across multiple tissues provides a rich resource for unraveling the etiology and drug mechanisms of complex diseases. However, traditional GWAS approaches, which focus on single genes, fail to capture the intricate interplay of genetic variants and biological processes that contribute to disease susceptibility.

**Content:**
The advent of high-throughput technologies has revolutionized our ability to study gene expression at a global scale. This has led to the development of powerful tools for integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data into GWAS analysis. These methods provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and diseases.

**Conclusion:**
The application of TWAS has significantly advanced our understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms. However, its focus on the individual gene level limits its ability to capture complex interactions at the network level. By employing TWAS, researchers can identify not only individual genetic risk factors but also the intricate interplay of genetic variants and biological processes that contribute to disease susceptibility.

"While gene expression data has proven valuable in understanding disease etiology and disease-risk prediction, the ability to identify and elucidate the intricate network of biological processes that underpin disease remains a significant challenge. Identifying disease etiology and drug mechanisms requires a comprehensive understanding of the genetic architecture of complex traits. While traditional GWAS relies on assessing individual gene expression, recent research has highlighted the importance of integrating information from a broader network of genes through approaches such as transcriptional-wide association studies (TWAS). TWAS has proven to be a powerful tool for uncovering the genetic basis of complex diseases, including cancer and cardiovascular disorders. However, its ability to capture interactions across the genome at the individual gene level is a significant limitation. This limitation is addressed by focusing on a broader set of genes and pathways through a network-based approach, thereby providing a more comprehensive understanding of the genetic architecture of complex traits.

## Integrating gene expression data in TWAS: A window into complex disease etiology and drug repurposing.

Despite its success in uncovering disease etiology through GWAS, TWAS has limitations. By focusing on individual genes, it fails to capture the intricate network interactions that underpin complex diseases. This knowledge gap motivates the exploration of alternative approaches that can integrate gene expression data into GWAS analysis. Here, we explore the potential of integrating transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) with gene expression data to gain a deeper mechanistic understanding of disease etiology and identify novel therapeutic targets.

**Context:**
The field of genetic research has made significant strides in identifying genetic variants associated with complex diseases, including cancer and drug resistance. However, existing approaches, such as transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), have limitations in capturing the intricate interplay between genetic variants and disease risk.

**Content:**
This manuscript presents a novel approach to address this limitation by leveraging the power of gene expression data. By integrating information from gene co-expression networks, we gain a mechanistic understanding of genetic associations beyond the individual gene level. This approach, termed clustering of complex traits (CCT), facilitates the discovery of novel therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities.

**Conclusion:**
The inclusion of gene expression data in the analysis framework offers a powerful means to elucidate the etiology of diseases and identify novel therapeutic strategies. By bridging the gap between individual gene and network-level approaches, this study paves the way for a more comprehensive understanding of complex diseases and the development of personalized treatments.

Integrating large-scale gene expression data into functional genomics approaches offers a powerful avenue for dissecting disease etiology and identifying therapeutic targets. However, traditional approaches focusing solely on individual genes fail to capture the intricate network-level interactions that underpin complex diseases. Recent advancements in transcriptomic research have highlighted the potential of transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) in elucidating the etiology of diseases by integrating information from genome-wide expression data. TWAS has proven remarkably successful in unraveling the genetic architecture of various diseases, including cancer and cardiovascular disorders, by identifying genetic variants associated with disease risk and progression. Notably, TWAS has been instrumental in uncovering disease mechanisms and developing personalized therapeutic strategies through repurposing of existing drugs.

## Integrating gene co-expression and functional genomics for disease etiology and drug repurposing.

Despite the wealth of genetic data, identifying the biological processes underlying complex diseases remains a significant challenge. While traditional GWAS approaches have proven successful in uncovering disease etiology at the single-gene level, they fail to capture the intricate interactions occurring at the network level. This is particularly relevant in diseases with multiple genetic causes, where a single genetic variant may be implicated in disease development through diverse pathways.

By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data into GWAS, we can leverage the strengths of both approaches. This approach provides a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings by identifying the co-expression of genes in disease-associated pathways. This information can guide the discovery of novel therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities.

However, TWAS has a limitation at the individual gene level, as it does not capture complex interactions at the network level. Moreover, TWAS has been shown to be effective in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing, highlighting its potential for both disease etiology and drug discovery.

  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Does not make up references to other articles"
type = "Information accuracy"
score = 2.0

import re

input = context["vars"]["content"]

references = {
  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
  "@pmid:33931583",
  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
  "@pmid:31036433",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
}

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because
#  references might be removed from the input in some cases)
references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]

# capture current references in the output using a regex
output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)

n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not in references])
res = (n_fake_refs == 0)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

vars.title: file://./inputs/title.txt
vars.keywords: file://./inputs/keywords.txt
vars.content: file://./inputs/doesnt_start_with_context.md

assert.value:
description = "Starts with context"
type = "Structure"
full_score = 2.0
reason = "Failed"

# make sure TWAS is spelled out in the first two sentences
first_two_sentences = ". ".join(output.split(". ")[:2]).lower()

res = "transcription-wide association stud" in first_two_sentences
if res:
  reason = "Passed (full score)"
  score = full_score
else:
  res = "transcriptome-wide association stud" in first_two_sentences
  if res:
    reason = "Passed (half score)"
    score = full_score / 2.0

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": reason,
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

vars.title: file://./inputs/title.txt
vars.keywords: file://./inputs/keywords.txt
vars.content: file://./inputs/doesnt_end_with_conclusion.md

assert.value:
description = "Ends with conclusion"

# get last two sentences
last_sentences = ". ".join(output.split(". ")[-2:]).lower()

keywords = [
  "however",
  "nevertheless",
  "nonetheless",
  "limitation",
  "despite",
  "though",
  "even though",
]

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Has roughly the same length as input"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

input = context["vars"]["content"]
input_words = len(input.strip().split())
output_words = len(output.strip().split())

res = (output_words > 0.5 * input_words) and (output_words < 1.5 * input_words)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}
